question.title: Why I am not able to get exact matches when I perform template-matching?
question.body:
I am performing a simple template matching but for the life of me I still not able to find out why I am not getting correct matches. I've tried without converting to grayscale and to remove the alpha channel from the template but sadly it did not help. I've also tried with a scale invariant approach but did not help either.

This is the template:

And this is the image:

And this what I am doing:

public static boolean isIconPresent(String largeImagePath, String iconPath, double threshold) {
        // Load images
        Mat largeImageColor = Imgcodecs.imread(largeImagePath);
        Mat iconColor = Imgcodecs.imread(iconPath);

        if (largeImageColor.empty() || iconColor.empty()) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Could not load images.");
        }

        // Convert to grayscale (optional)
        Mat largeImage = new Mat();
        Mat icon = new Mat();
        Imgproc.cvtColor(largeImageColor, largeImage, Imgproc.COLOR_BGR2GRAY);
        Imgproc.cvtColor(iconColor, icon, Imgproc.COLOR_BGR2GRAY);

        // Result matrix
        int resultCols = largeImage.cols() - icon.cols() + 1;
        int resultRows = largeImage.rows() - icon.rows() + 1;
        Mat result = new Mat(resultRows, resultCols, CvType.CV_32FC1);

        // Template matching
        Imgproc.matchTemplate(largeImage, icon, result, Imgproc.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED);

        // Get match location
        Core.MinMaxLocResult mmr = Core.minMaxLoc(result);
        Point matchLoc = mmr.maxLoc;
        double maxVal = mmr.maxVal;

        System.out.println("Match confidence: " + maxVal);

        return maxVal >= threshold;
    }

answers.body:
Template scale

Make sure to scale your template to the expected size first. Otherwise the matching will never work or you need a scale-invariant matching method such a Fourier-Mellin transform. I eyeballed the icon size to 170x170 pixels.

Implementation problems

There are two major problems with your code:

  1. You are using the wrong transform to grayscale. It should be COLOR_BGRA2GRAY in Imgproc.cvtColor(iconColor, icon, Imgproc.COLOR_BGR2GRAY); such that the alpha channel is taken into account or you have to restrict your matrix to the first three channels prior to conversion.
Match confidence: 0.9356115460395813
  1. The problem upon matching is your border/the transparent region around the template. First of all, normalized cross-correlation, Imgproc.TM_CCORR_NORMED, is the better choice for matching your data. Additionally, Imgproc.TM_CCORR_NORMED supports using masked-matching. You can create a mask using the alpha-channel of your icon: Set the mask to 255 where alpha > 0 and 0 elsewhere.
Match confidence: 0.9811655879020691

Extension: Dynamic scaling

Using a dynamic scaling, it is also possible to use the original icon size and match each scaled resolution. With 2.0..4.0 in 0.2 steps normalized cross-correlation finds the correct four positions with highest confidence (threshold = 0.98):

Match 0: Location: (670, 1284), Confidence: 0.99, Icon shape: (154, 154)
Match 1: Location: (776, 1468), Confidence: 0.99, Icon shape: (154, 154)
Match 2: Location: (564, 1101), Confidence: 0.99, Icon shape: (154, 154)
Match 3: Location: (882, 1652), Confidence: 0.99, Icon shape: (154, 154)

question_comments.body: to be clear, TM_SQDIFF* should work best with this, since there are no lighting changes to these "sprites"/billboards.

it's always the same problem. bad choice of TM_*. that is vital, and more important than all the other considerations. -- and YES, the template has a scale that's different from the instances in the haystack. fix that and it'll work.

Dynamic scaling is not a problem here. I used 2.0 .. 4.0 in 0.2 steps as scale factor and it would return the correct 4 locations with 0.99 confidence.
Yes, please, as otherwise I would need to dynamically scale the template. I would much appreciate it.

I chose a rather blunt way of opening your large image in an image viewer, dragging a rectangle around the target structure and eyeballing it to ~170x170 pixels. Even if you do not get the size perfectly the template matching will still work reasonably. If you need scale invariance I can plug it into my Fourier-Mellin code and check whether this template/image combination works well.
